article.description:
James Posey had 26 points to lead six players in
double figures as Denver beat the depleted Houston Rockets 101-70 Tuesday night in the Nuggets' home finale.
article.headline: Nuggets hold Rockets to 27 first-half points
article.linkText: Nuggets win home finale vs. depleted Rockets
article.story:
DENVER (AP) -- Alley-oops, chest-bumping, dancing along the sidelines and plenty of smiles. After a season of turmoil and disappointment, the Denver Nuggets had a great time in their home finale.
Posey

James Posey had 26 points to lead six players in double figures as the Nuggets beat the depleted Houston Rockets 101-70 on Tuesday night. "That was fun," coach Mike Evans said. "The fans went away feeling good about this team tonight and I think that was important. The way they played, the fans had to go away feeling good." Denver jumped on Houston early and never let up. The Nuggets set a team record by holding the Rockets to 27 points in the first half and tied the record for points allowed in a game. Denver had nine dunks -- five by Posey -- and just six turnovers. Rookie Chris Anderson, playing in just his 23rd game, capped the victory with an alley-oop dunk and a strut down the sideline. "It was fun out there," said Posey, who shot 11-for-17 from the field. "It would have been easy for us lay it down because we're playing for nothing, but we've got pride and we just wanted to finish strong." Denver has won three straight overall and six in a row at home, its longest home winning streak since taking nine straight in January 2001. Houston shot 30 percent to lose for the seventh time in eight games. The loss ensured the Rockets will not win 30 games for first time since 1983-84. Houston, which has been plagued by injury problems all season, has lost five of six on the road. The Rockets need to beat Portland on Wednesday to avoid their worst road record since going 10-31 in 1989-90. "I hate what happened to us, but things happen to people and the main thing is how you let it affect you," Houston coach Rudy Tomjanovich said. "I wouldn't change the direction we are going one iota. "We've seen teams a lot farther along than us and have not nearly as much adversity as us that don't make the playoffs." Oscar Torres led the Rockets with 18 points, and Terence Morris added 14. Kelvin Cato and Dan Langhi returned after missing Sunday's game with injuries, but Steve Francis (shoulder), Cuttino Mobley (flu) and Kevin Willis (knee tendinitis) did not play. With leading scorer and rebounder Juwan Howard out for the second straight game, Evans had to rely on his younger players. They responded. Donnell Harvey and Carlos Arroyo had 12 points each, Zendon Hamilton finished with 11 and Andersen had nine. Kenny Satterfield finished with 12 assists. All five players are in their first or second year in the league. "We've been having a pretty good time, especially here lately," Evans said. "We've had some fun and we've beaten some teams that we weren't expected to beat." Houston was 7-for-21 and scored just 14 points in the first quarter, but it got even worse in the second. The Rockets closed a 10-point deficit to 26-23 on a layup by Jason Collier with 7:49 left in the second quarter, but went 1-for-10 and had six turnovers the rest of the half. Denver closed the first half with a 19-4 run to lead 45-27. The Nuggets' previous low for points allowed in a half was 28 by Seattle in the second half of a game Oct. 31, 1985. For the Rockets, it wasn't even their worst half of the season. Houston had just 24 points in the first half of a 90-86 loss to San Antonio on Nov. 13. The 70 points was their third-lowest total ever. "You have to get out there and play hard and give what you've got," Houston's Moochie Norris said. "That's what we get paid for, especially the backups, for the chance to step in and showcase themselves and take advantage of the minutes." Denver extended the lead to 54-29 after Posey had a three-point play on a dunk over Cato with 8:56 left in the third quarter. Houston had nine players in uniform after dressing the NBA minimum of eight against Memphis on Sunday. Game notes
Denver point guard George McCloud, who had surgery for a corneal abrasion Saturday, did not play. ... Houston is 7-17 on the road against the Western Conference. ... The Nuggets finished 5-0 at home in April. ... Houston scored less than 80 points for the 16th time this season.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
